commentBody:
This forum’s not quite what it was
It’s minus a bit of its buzz
Replies have gone ghostly
But certainly mostly
I’m missing “I done did this puzz”
We missed you Tom!
Etc[etera] = *and* other things; among other things = inter alia.

Thank you for this delightful puzzle! I now live in California but Pittsburgh is the first city I lived in when I came to US decades ago. This puzzle brought me back to the fond memories of the city. Also remembered another favorite Pittsburghese - ‘n’at!

Well that was certainly a groanworthy theme, although I had to read Wordplay to appreciate the missing H angle.   PARKOUR and HECTOR made it all worthwhile.  

I had a college roommate from PITTSBURGH who once puzzled me by asking for a gum band.  It took me longer than it should have to figure out that that was PITTSBURGHese for rubber band.

This was very likely my fastest Wednesday finish. I thought the theme was cute, but I definitely didn’t need to make use of it to solve the puzzle; I just ignored the crossed-out clues until I finished it up and then went back to figure out the H-dropping theme.
Very cool puzzle! Loved the 'today I learned' info about Pittsburgh, and creative way to build a puzzle from that. Well done!
Fun theme but I have to ask does the constructor (or the editors) fly first class? Because I can’t remember the last time I ever saw a footrest in the main cabin.
Is the theater pictured in Pittsburgh??  Wow!

My father lived in Pittsburg, CA.  I was able to travel there a few times before he passed away.  He mentioned the connection to Pittsburgh, and today I learned about the temporarily-dropped H that occurred while Pittsburgh was founded.

Being in the East Bay, it’s a nice ride on BART to San Francisco.  Rides on cable cars and excursions to Pier 39 left fun memories.  Pittsburgh itself is a temperate and driveable suburb.

All the grandkids are within a couple of miles of my wife and me, so I’m not moving there.  Mr. McCoy, thanks for bringing back some pleasant memories.

Ah, Marc Chagall. A stunning example of how deeply rooted identity and displacement can become transcendent forces in art. His work floats between worlds, both literally and figuratively: shtetl and city, sacred and profane, memory and myth. His autobiography is also a work of art, if not outright poetry.

And ah, Uther Pendragon. 

“Marth ys kywreith Vthyr pen”

“Wondrous was the wisdom of Uther the chief dragon.”

From Elegy for Uther Pendragon in Old Welsh (Marwnat Vthyr Pen[dragon]), attributed to Taliesin. 

Thank you for an excellent puzzle, Tom, one that doth stir the mind and scatter the neurons into all kinds of directions worth pursuing.

Based on some football games I’ve seen, I think Pittsburgh used to have a population of around 140 million people.

Also thank you for cluing 27A differently but I think that word’s just ruined for me forever.

This had me feeling like a whizz, and like a fizzle. 

Nice job!

As a Pittsburgher born and bred, I feel seen, along with fellow 'Burghers Al, Josh, Sue, and I think there's one or two others, all of us representing our (not very) fair city with aplomb.

There's a Pittsburgh, Kansas that spells it the correct way, and Pittsburg, California (we regard them with contempt). In 1891, the US Department of Geographic Names decreed that all towns ending in --burgh must standardize and drop the "h." Perhaps there was some hidden anti-German sentiment at work there, too, who knows? For years I assumed that Pittsburgh was unique, but apparently a number of other towns across the US had to comply.

Some did not. It costs a lot to change letterhead and signage, and plus, there were those revanchists eager to reclaim that lost "h" as if its loss were a mortal blow to their dignity and civic pride. Some refused to drop the H and continued to publish their newspapers and magazines with the H intact, which led to heated disputes, jabbing the air with their cigars, threats of caning, and stern rebukes in the editorials of those papers bereft of H who took their cues from the millionaire's row. Incidentally, Tesla worked in Pittsburgh just prior to our dropping the H, basically providing Westinghouse with the workings of alternating current. Westinghouse paid him a pittance for his inventions. There's amoral in that story.

TOP-NOTCH puzzle, Mr. McCoy! Not only did I immensely enjoy the solve itself, I immensely enjoyed the wonderful feeling of getting what the themers were all about once the revealer came up. It's always the icing on the cake (a school bus cake, of course, with OREOs for wheels) when we get the theme, isn't it? For a musical accompaniment today, please enjoy Simply Red with "STARs," live in Hamburg (which has never had an "H" at the end) and do note Mike Hucknall's awesome artwork shirt (albeit not a Chagall)– https://youtu.be/HJmk25b4Acs?si=Pay1WTNdvlJrQOoC Thank you, Mr. McCoy, for reasserting my already established love of a Wednesday puzzle!
"do the mat!" I laughed til I cried. Thank you for this bit of extreme levity.

Loved the clue for TESLA (as opposed to clues mentioning that car company my friends and I have been picketing on the weekends or that man who is its largest shareholder.)  

If you haven't seen "The Prestige," it's available to stream. We've seen it multiple times and recommend it every chance we get. Oh look, I'm doing it again.

The theme was interesting and educational, although I didn't love DOTHEMAT(H). I Googled a bunch to see if there really is a dance move called "the mat" (could be similar to the worm) but it seems to just be a silly joke. I'm sure some people got a kick out of it. Didn't hit my funny bone, but that's on me. I would have preferred both entries with and without the H to be real expressions. 

Please let me know if I'm missing something.

Like a certain protégé, a missed connection from LIFEVEST to FOOTREST downgraded my strut to Goldstar.  No first class happy music - should've reread the clue. Gearup,  we're flying the uther way.
It's Blue Star tonight, folks.

G. Gekko: [with a smirk on his face]
"Sand bagged me on Bluestar huh? I guess you think you taught the teacher a lesson that the tail can wag the dog huh? Well let me clue you in, pal. The ice is melting right underneath your feet."

Guess I can putupwith another grid tomorrow!
Haha, loved this one! So much wit! The entries left me smiling throughout. The theme was very clever, and once I got it, produced even more smiles. My vote for Wednesday puzzle of the year.

Any puzzle with a David Bowie (RIP) reference is okay by me.
An odd theme that grew on me after completing the puzzle. And I appreciated the fresh and somewhat fresh cluing for OREO and TESLA, respectively, though I now have a Wheels on the Bus earworm.  And though I'm not as eloquent as Ms Lyons, Marc Chagall and UTHER Pendragon were most welcome.

Interesting puzzle, and I noticed the with/without Hs theming fairly early. As for the city, I've been through the one with the H, and through one without (in SE Kansas). Lots more differences that just the Hs, though.

Didn't have much trouble with the puzzle until the end, then had to track down an incorrect entry, so that cost me some time, but then I don't really care about times now.

Thanks, Tom.
Feels just a bit tougher than a Monday, probably because the clues are not intentionally misleading. If I found it easy many probably can do it in 5 mins or less.

I grew up near Pittsburgh and in reference to the mention of the phrase the car 'needs washed', you would most often hear 'I have to wersh the car'. I'd also have to 'red up my room', tell my friends 'see yinz guys later', yell at my sister to stay out of my room and stop being so 'nebby' and ask Mom if I could have a 'pop' instead of milk with dinner. Ah, Pittsburgh, such a great little city. Our family spent a lot of time there enjoying the museums, restaurants, Pirates ball games (I even remember the ivy covered walls of old Forbes Field)...I haven't been back in decades, but when I hear that accent, I'm right there again. Thanks for the nostalgic puzzle, really enjoyed it.

"Did you know that a writing implement in Pittsburgh doubles as a meteorological device?"
"I've seen a pencil vane, yeah."

(And when their baseball team sells desserts, they have good pie rates.)
Dubious theme. “Do the mat”? “Put up wit”? Sure, Jan.

My poor little birthday child, just for a moment, had teensy bus wheels made with ORZO.

I visited xwordinfo to see when we last heard from Tom McCoy (July 2022) - while there I was reminded of his puzzle on 3/18/21. Highly recommended, if you haven’t done that one.

How many ways can you describe an OREO? At least one more, it seems! And as long as the clues are as fresh and charming as this, I don’t mind the cookie’s umpteenth entry at all. The chocolate wheels on the bus go round and round, round and round… and make me nostalgic for my own childhood cakes.
Loved this theme! First Wednesday I've done so fast with no clues. even the strange words could be figured out with some time. I have a new goofy dance move to try :)

Ah, Pittsburgh, where I spent my first year of college and the first city I ever lived in. "I'm goin' dahntahn to buy a pahnd of grahnd rahnd."  Black snow, the smell of the steel mills at night (it was a while ago), Yuengling beer, and don't forget those Stillers!

I have nothing nice or interesting to say about the puzzle itself (I did it, let's leave it at that) but I have an observation about the recent comment section bug - it affects older puzzles, too. I just did a puzzle from 2022 and checked the commnets there: just like at present, things are iffy, and they weren't before. Whatever the IT people did, it affects all posts, also archival ones.

I honestly had such a hard time with this on my first pass, though I haven’t the slightest idea why. I just couldn’t break through. I came back a while later and it all clicked. I’m still laughing (out loud) at DOTHEMAT. 🤣

A lot of  Pittsburgh biggies, the three W's: Frank Lloyd Wright, Andy Warhol, August Wilson, and a bunch of other names, including Gene Kelly, Perry Como, Rachel Carson—something for everyone. Who knew?

I've never thought much about Pittsburgh, never having been anywhere near the place, but I see that it must be a most interesting city.

Thank you for the puzzle, Tom McCoy.  The puzzle clues were great fun and added a lot to this one.

This was fun and clever and I enjoyed learning about Pittsburgh. My own town has a history of adding and dropping letters at the end as well. The town was incorporated in 1881 as Spokan Falls. In 1883, the "e" was added to the end because the mayor thought it looked more sophisticated or something.  The "Falls" was dropped in 1891, and here we are.

Since several of us are talking about home towns.  Mine is a Spanish named town:  Pueblo, Colorado.

What's Pueblo Spanish for?  Town.

My home town didn't even bother to get a real name.

GPS Datum was a bit of a misdirect for those of us familiar with mapping software. Datum has a specific meaning in the spatial context which makes using the more general meaning here feel quite unsatisfying.

Since the constructor was lenient now we have to twirl our thumbs until the next one. Yes I know there’s the archive, but what fun is it not being able to write querulous comments about the day’s puzzle and getting flamed for it?

This one stumped me flat out for about three hours until I finally took off the blindfold I was wearing.  After that I solved it in just under 14 min.  Must be a glitch in my app though, I never got the congratulations screen with the jazz piano music, despite my solving all clues and filling each square in with the correct rebus answer MICKEY ROONEY.

I liked this one a lot. It took a bit to figure out the theme entries but enjoyed them once they were solved. DO THE MAT (44A) is my favorite! Also loved the unique cluing for OREO (5D). I enjoyed reading everyone’s comments about Pittsburgh. Sounds like an interesting city! Isn’t that where the Pearsons are from (This is Us)? I don’t recall any of them speaking Pittsburghese. Hmm … Great show, though!

Ok—“fighting iris” is the funniest crossword answer ever. I know it wasn’t the actual answer. But the idea of it is just cracking me up. I keep picturing this ferocious little eyeball and I’m dissolving in laughter. 🤣🤺👁️ Thanks Mr. McCoy!
For yinz Pittsburghers: Forget the H, do you remember when there was an O in Pittsburgh?  Right on Forbes, best Cheesesteaks and fries ever. But nO O nO mO.

I’ve been doing the NYT crosswords for a couple of years now, and this was my very first complete 100% solve without one single look up or help at all - and pretty swiftly too.  I do believe this may be a fairly easy solve for a Wednesday, but I am still chuffed at this milestone!
I liked this theme! And I loved how the revealer clue made it clear what was happening. Very fun
I briefly considered logi for 18A and anticipated a major uproar in the comments.

"Fighting iris"? Wince.
I enjoyed this one, despite the excruciating puns. More than usually in my wheelhouse, with the obvious exception of the aforementioned Fighting Irish.

A point from the constructor's notes. Like Pittsburghese, constructions of the form "The car needs washed" are very common in Scottish English. Whereas in Northern England you hear "The car wants washing", which always slightly fazes me.
Fun! Thanks Tom.
I wonder where Uther Pendragon's son got those coconuts?
Fresh, fun, and witty.

I was all set to dislike this one, starting with the mild annoyance that the developers could not render the strikeouts in the clues in the pdf version(s) and then the decidedly off beat theme/reveal.  But Sam's column got me off that (not too) high horse.  Nicely done. 

For staring contests I practice with a mirror but it always ends in a draw.

Clever and I got to learn 
Pittsburgh-y things!

I can still smell the new box of
64 Crayola crayons 🖍️ 
with the sharpener on the back.

It meant 
new school year, and
we weren’t *that* poor that month.

Lovely Wednesday.

Thank you Tom!

Mr. Fairbanks Jr. angry about having to play an old prospector?
-Nope.
-Yup.

SOURDOUGH

(Did your eyes roll,
or do you have a fighting iris?
Which is just a great, hilarious, corny image :)
Can someone please explain AMPS and PARKOUR?

That was different. Managed to work it out, but will admit I remained appropriately puzzled by the theme answers until I was almost done. Just made for a nice 'aha' moment when it finally dawned on me. 

And... there was only one debut answer in this puzzle and it was... FIGHTINGIRISH. Really surprised to see that that had never appeared before. 

And, of course I have my puzzle finds today. I'll put those in replies. 

...
Yinz are clever. Thanks from Pittsburgh.

I lit up when I saw Tom’s name atop this puzzle.  It’s been three years since his last Times puzzle, and his puzzles are rife with wit and humor.  His mind is askew in a marvelous way, and his puzzles feel out-of-the-box.  

Here he went with the fact that Pittsburgh spent a period without that final H, and rather than move on, he contrived this off-the-wall theme that totally charmed me.

A puzzle sparked by glints of wackorama.  FIGHTING IRIS?  [Let’s see that dance move where you lie flat by a door!”]?  Hah!  

A puzzle beautified by answers such as INTREPID, ENMITIES, REALM and HECTOR.

A puzzle marked by a new and lovely clue for OREO, which has appeared 500 times in the Times alone.  That is tough to do.  Go  ahead – try doing the same!

I entered this puzzle with that smile at seeing your name, Tom, and left it grateful for your skill, talent, and eccentric excellence.  This one pushed so many happy buttons!

I’ve been mulling over since last night how I feel about this theme. 

Sure, it’s a subjective matter, especially considering that we have never seen such three-line clues with all those cross-outs (and the tiny font that I didn’t appreciate).

But to me, the connection between the revealer and the theme answers was tenuous at best. PITTSBURGH started out with an H, lost it, and then got it back again. This is a detail you could care about only if you live there or are a Pennsylvania state historian. And the H-less “answers” (FIGHTING IRIS???) were just so strange. 

Nothing technically wrong, but this one had me scratching my chin.

41D. C'mon, they're not that olde!
I enjoyed the puzzle. Notre Dame's team helped me crack it.

Now, I need to know the backstory on 62A's final letter.
Just a simple crossword with a forced theme in the clues.

This puzzle was easy enough that one didn’t need the extra “clue.” It would be more interesting if the “real” clues were more obscure and necessitated using the secondary clues. 

I did not even “get” the crossed out clues until I finished the puzzle. Ho hum.
The theme felt more like a diversion than a puzzle to solve, but still kinda clever.  I do have to ask if this is the same Gary Larson who makes the Far Side comics.

I am often frustrated with clues that come especially from male puzzle creators - emphasis on sports arcana and video games - but today's puzzle starting out with "Manly," with an answer of "macho?"  Many women, especially older feminists like me, would say that is the opposite of manly.
Where are the female puzzle builders?  I know there are occasional ones - And why soooooo much emphasis on pop culture?  I am not conversant with most current pop stars - 
As an older adult, I want to be able to be competitive - I love the crosswords, and have been doing them for decades.
The premise is a bit strained but it was fun enough. Thanks! I liked seeing HECTOR.
I guess it just shows how old I am-I was thinking lps or even eps for the old music player. Never cds.
Fun clue for OREO (which I never mind seeing in a puzzle)  also fun to learn about the H and PittsburgH.  Looking forward to more from Tom.

The second and third themers were definitely stretches -- whether or not one enjoyed the stretching -- but PEACE MARC was no stretch and a pleasant reminder for me: https://www.un.org/en/visitor-centre-new-york/peace-window-marc-chagall
My inexplicable certainty in the answers GRAPHS, LPS, and WEEP added to the degree of difficulty.
10 out of 10 for this one.  A delightfully entertaining solve.  Nice work, Tom McCoy!
Some Dad humor for a Wednesday...and a new twist on OREO cluing. Thanks Tom!
The connection between AMPS and theaters is tenuous. AMPS can be found in lots of places (stadiums, arenas, teenagers bedrooms, etc). I rarely complain about clues, but this one was weak.

Not sure why I can't see in the comments this post The Times told me has posted (and I can see on the link provided) but some people can see it? B Barry Ancona New York NY9m ago The second and third themers were definitely stretches -- whether or not one enjoyed the stretching -- but PEACE MARC was no stretch and a pleasant reminder for me: https://www.un.org/en/visitor-centre-new-york/peace-window-marc-chagall Reply2 RecommendedShare
Surprised at the amount of negative feedback!  I was so thrilled to finally see a fresh, unique theme.
I really like "A little bit of everything" and its answer.
This was fun. Beat my average. Thanks!
Y'all (and yinz) must go solve today's Wordle after solving this. You'll see why... HA!

Flagrantly absurd theme!



My work here on Earth is done.

I really enjoyed this one.  Much more fun / clever / challenging than most of last week.  The theme revealed itself slowly and by the time I got down to the revealer it was a gentle "oh, cute" moment.

I haven't read the comments today but someone mentioned it got a negative reaction?  That surprises me.  To each his own....
Never heard of PARKOUR before now, but I'm glad to learn something new.

Lots of "new to me" in this puzzle...still, for a Wednesday, I am proud to say I did quite well. In the end, it was kind of a My Fair Lady clue... and your ear worm for today...

 "Hear them down in SoHo Square,
Dropping aitches [Hs] everywhere
Speaking English any way they like!"

From the first scene where Professor Higgins sings "Why Can't the English (Teach Their Children How to Speak)?"

I thought the puzzle was quite clever, and yet, for a Wednesday, I was able to get through it in decent time. I never heard of PARKOUR, and don't expect to come across UTHER again, unless it's in a puzzle, but I thought the theme was quite clever.

I wish you all a dandy day.

Customer Care replied to my question yesterday regarding the issue with the View All Replies function and a question came up: 

Are folks viewing comments within the Games App seeing the same problem or is it only those of us using a browser?
This theme is asinine. Not even clever by a percent.

Took this Irishman too long to get HECK. 

Far too many mild expletives in my vocabulary.
What the heck is a 19A (PARKOUR) and how does it make an obstacle course in the city? I was hoping that the essay would explain it. Can someone enlighten me?

Dang. Got caught on TSA/star simply because I was solving on my phone and typed TSS. I knew it was TSA. Heck, I’ll hector myself all night over that. Had never heard of hector before though I know a Hector that occasionally makes me want to hector myself over his behavior

I've never constructed a puzzle, but, as I understand it, you start with a theme, come up with four or five themed answers and then work on the fill.

The theme here could have been Wednesday-level amusing, but the themed answers seemed to me to lack something.
PEACE, MARC?  OK, I guess.
PUT-UP WIT?  Barely acceptable.
FIGHTING IRIS???
DO THE MAT???
I don't think so.  At least they don't "do it" for me.  (It even felt to me that Sam was apologetic for the level of WIT exhibited.  "Kind of ridiculous"?  Can that be good?)

Respect to all puzzle-makers who get accepted by the Times...and also to those who don't.  I sincerely admire your efforts,....but I don't always like them.

There were two prominent Pitts, Pitt the Elder, Earl Chatham, and his son, Pitt the Younger. Both had distinguished careers, worth reading up on. Because of their sympathy for the American cause, their names are all over the United States of America. Chatham is primarily a county name (honoring the father), but also used for towns and other places; Pitt is usually honoring the son and usually used for cities and towns.
I used to live in Pittsboro, in Chatham County, North Carolina. The town is named for Pitt the Younger, the county for his father, Earl of Chatham.

Those European revolutionaries and forward-thinkers who supported the nascent USA are honored here, there, and everywhere: Lafayette, Kościuszko, Pulaski, von Steuben. We would never have won the war of independence without their assistance, and all for idealism.

The H, you say!

I never can remember whether to spell Pittsburg, or Edinburg, or others of that ilk, as burg or burgh or borough.

Clever gimmick and construction. Thanks, Tom.

Now to scroll down and see if Mike has PUT UP WIT.

solved the puzzle easily but i still don't understand the theme.
This happens to me a lot.
Like, I just ignored the words that were crossed out.
Love the Wordle - Crossword connection today!

PARKOUR is spelled with a K?!?!

I was certain it was spelled PARCOUR. Did it not originate in France?

Avoid spoilers until after the View All Replies button, if that shows up.

Strands #430
“Training day”
🔵🔵🔵🔵
🟡🔵🔵

Methinks the emus need some more training to get the comments posting properly.
The theme clues were fun.  Thank you for a smooth, charming solve.

I’m sorry, but since when do airplane seats have footrests?? Have I been missing them all these years, or just flying the wrong airlines? Buses, sure, but airplanes? Not any that I’ve ever traveled on!

Fine puzzle, but the theme was a dud in my opinion. The h-less entries were a stretch at best, and the historical accuracy gained by the first strikeout in the clue was just clutter. No “aha” pleasure at the reveal for me.

Putting that aside, I enjoyed the solve and thought it was a typical Wednesday-level experience.

And once again, I’m surprised to see complaints about what I thought was a thoroughly delightful puzzle. I understand that not everyone loves every puzzle, but is the snark really necessary? 
So back to you, Tom McCoy. Thank you for brightening my morning with this clever theme. Please keep them coming. I did a Master’s in Linguistics and then taught ESL to adults. I loved it, and today I loved learning about Pittsburghese and “yinz”.

Link to May's Bonus Puzzle. https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/bonus/2025/05?campaign_id=268&emc=edit_gp_20250507&instance_id=153935&nl=gameplay®i_id=10312429&segment_id=197469&user_id=512f327e01370471591d63ebff1858e7

There are  365  or 366 crossword puzzles in a NYT year.  Some will not be to your liking.  RELAX, people.  Chill out.  If you are confused on the theme, read the blog, if you have access.  And some puzzling answers are "fact" answers and can be Googled or Wiki'd.    Too much negativity in the comments.  If you can't say something nice, don't say anything.   And if you want to see the replies to your comments, get a Puzzles subscription.  We can cut the comments down considerably, with "I liked this puzzle" with 500 agrees, and "I done did this puzz" with 500 people agreeing with Eddie.   We have enough negativity on both sides in our politics.  We don't need it here.   And we don't need people trying to build up daily streaks of commenting.  (I admit, I am getting into that habit as well.)  Peace.

That was a breeze for me, just 3 seconds over my best ever time for a Wednesday, but very enjoyable. Great OREO clue as mentioned in the article :)
No complaints about the theme, I always enjoy a bit of silliness, although it wasn't vital and I didn't get it while solving. Interesting to learn about Pittsburg(h), and I'll remember the proper spelling now thanks to Mr McCoy! Going back and working out the theme at the end was satisfying and made me chuckle.
Thanks Tom!

I guess we broke the comments system again. 

As of 9:40 MDT Wednesday, there are 48 comments, with the most recent time stamp “11 hours ago.”

Those emus must be sitting on quite a large clutch.
Nice constructor notes! Good Wednesday puzzle. I was slowed down a bit b/c I had BERATE instead of HECTOR. Both words that are v evocative and kinda sound like what they are?
Which is used more: Oreo in the Crossword or Acacia/Acai in Spelling Bee?
Great Wednesday puzzle -- breezy, fun, just challenging enough.  Thanks!

220 comments, and nobody has mentioned "gumbands?" (That's what the Yinzers call rubber bands.)

A week ago, I saw a car in the parking lot with a DE license plate that read, YINZ. They also had a Steelers decal next to it, in case you didn't get the joke. Anyway, I had to track down the owner and give respect - my sister and her husband went to Carnegie-Mellon.
Had no idea what the theme was until I checked the column after solving. Good fill though.

This is a trivial issue but please help!
Why would crayons be bought in packs of 8 or 168?
(I can buy crayons in packs of 8,12,20, 30 and so on)

Great crossword, and interesting comments.

It took me way too long to remember that "shed tears" could be past tense. Worse, I have been speaking English for about 87 years, and I couldn't have told you what INTREPID means! Or is it one of the words my "cognitive decline" has erased?

"Courageous" for 38D was one of the lookups that got me to a phony 24-day streak. But it took me an hour. I'm going to have to go back to using Autocheck soon.
That was a fun one!

Parkour? San Francisco can be an obstacle course at any time, but especially when there are citywide foot and bike races and a variety of parades. But I’ve never heard any referred to as a parkour. What is it?

PARKOUR was completely new to me. Spent at least five minutes simply reviewing for errors in the crosses before filling that one in.

Other than that, solved the puzzle in a reasonable amount of time for a Wednesday. Didn't much enjoy the theme. DOTHEMAT seemed particularly dopey. That said, INTREPID is a nice entry.

I was somewhat underwhelmed by the theme and understand why it would appeal to the constructor.  Some of the phrases, after removing the terminal H, were really a stretch in my mind.
But that’s me.

I will repeat a response I made to a reply from a few hours ago that is buried in the plethora of comments.  Please resist the urge to include a Wordle spoiler in your comments in this column.  I often don’t get to Wordle until later in the day and the comment today ruined it for me.  I could not unread it.  If I am not mistaken, there is a Wordle forum where such comments should be made.
If it wasn't for watching "The Office" I would've never hear of parkour. Now I know how to spell it but I never hear of anyone doing it. Hopefully, its "run it's course".

Loved this one. When I figured out the trick I had most of PEACEMARCH through crossings and I laughed out loud. After that I got the other themers pretty easily and broke out in a grin at each one. Fighting iris! I liked the creative valuing of OREO and now that I’ve read its origin story I like it even more. 

Very surprised that so many people have not heard of parkour. It’s been popular for at least 20 years. I think it was considered for the Olympics at one point. My kids have been to parkour birthday parties. A parkour party with a school bus cake with OREO wheels, now that would be something!
You kinda killed it today

The OREOs on the bus go round and round, round and round...  

Really enjoyed doing this puzzle. Was quite stymied by the crossed out clues, until I wasn't. Delightful theme! Love when a theme makes me chuckle out loud! 

I worried when my crosses spelled out PARKOUR but I was pretty sure everything was correct, so went with it. 

Out of fear of losing another comment today: and that is all I have to say about that!  (Get me, I'm finally learning brevity!)

Laurie Anderson discusses the [Manliness] of several common household objects: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6mRq1xgKykM (Salient segment begins at 1:40, but the introductory "Drum Dance" is pretty fun, too.)

My other puzzle find. Had other things to do earlier and never got to it. Anyway... a Sunday from July 18, 2010 by Robert W. Harris with the title: "Critical Periods." Don't recall ever seeing another one like this. A couple of theme clues and answers with the 'implied' answer listed below. "234, as of July 4, 2010?" ACCEPTEDUSAGE (Accepted U.S. age) "Workers in a global peace organization?" THEUNEMPLOYED (The U.N. employed). "Symmetrical power conductor for appliances?" BILATERALACCORD (Bi-lateral A.C. cord) "Pay in cash and your second surgery is half-price"?" STRANGEORDEAL (Strange O.R. deal) And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/18/2010&g=47&d=A ....
Very fun! A clue I found extra fun today (a part from the oreo one obvi): a little bit of everything for 'atom'. 😊
I know I'm biased but this Gameplay--and especially the Constructor Notes!--is the most charming EVER. And are you sure it needs washed, or do you just need to redd up?

Even more comment posting weirdness that I'm only noticing today.
When i look at Jane Wheelaghan's question about crayons, I see her comment, my response and DC's response. Fine. But if I use the time stamp, two comments show up between mine and David's, which were not visible before.  And they don't stay visible,  I  have to use the time stamp each time to view them.
I don't think I've ever felt older while solving a crossword than when I instinctively answered LPS for "Media for old music players", then had to delete that and type in CDS. Thanks, NYT!

Great puzzle today. The theme was obscure, but luckily I did not have to solve the theme in order to get the right answers. When the light dawned, that theme was an absolute hoot. Marc Chagall would have appreciated the namecheck.

I knew "parkour" from various suspense books featuring people younger, spryer. and bolder than I am.

Perfect Strands today; perfect Connections today (to get *one* of those perfect is extremely rare for me). However, the Mini was a challenge. Does anybody else think the Minis are getting more difficult? Maybe I'm just trying them too early in the day (never was, and never will be, a morning person).

Tom McCoy needs congratulated. More from him, please!

I'm a PITTSBURGH native, but for the last 30+ years I've lived in the San Francisco Bay Area. Out here we have a Pittsburg, without the final H. So whenever I say where I'm from, I always qualify that I'm from the genuine, named-for-William Pitt PITTSBURGH Pennsylvania, not one of the impostor cities like the one out here. ;-)

So much to love here—and of course I’m not at all biased! But I think Sam put it best when she observed that McCoy can “take a brief detour from clever to clownish and return as though nothing happened.” 

Also, while I’ve never fully embraced a non-ironic use of “yinz,” the “needs washed” (aka “needs red’ up”) construction really scratches a linguistic itch for me.

Only comment I want to share is that the first two theme clues beginning in P and ending in H (along with the relevant city) really made the later theme clues difficult. Like trying to fit a square peg in a round hole.

Fun puzzle, and a Wednesday PR for me. 

I first learned about PARKOUR from reading Seanan McGuire's InCryptid series. If you like urban fantasy, check her out!
I haven’t seen a 37 down on an airplane seat in a very long time.
I'm way after the fact, but I just have to say that I LOVED this puzzle. Great combination of...well...everything, mixed with a fun theme.

Oh my, I am truly late to this party, but count me in as a fan! This puzzle was simply delightful, beginning to end! @Eric Hougland

When we flew him to Europe last year, we couldn’t fly business because of what turns out to be widespread antifelinism in all but economy class. That’s when we found that Lufthansa economy had those absolutely useless footrests. @Bill in Yokohama above is spot on that it’s a useless gesture to make the passenger feel special when, in fact, it furthers your comfort in absolutely no way whatsoever. What it did do for us was leave zero room for my husband’s size 12 feet next to Señor Gato’s carrier jammed under the now further reduced space under the seat. This puzzle seem to be casting a very wide net, which strikes me is there a Wednesday like. At least there were no made up words.

@john ezra

As a kid, I always liked Pittsburgh.  I'd never been there.  Still haven't.

But I grew up in Pueblo, Colorado, which was a major steel producer, and nicknamed "Pittsburgh of the West".  I looked *everywhere* for something about my town to be proud of, and that was as close as I could come.

It occurred to me that it might not be a compliment when I saw pictures of massive air pollution in Pittsburgh in the 50s.

But I rooted for the Pirates for years because of that connection.

@john ezra Hello, also from Pittsburgh! Hope yinz survived the pahr ahtage n'at! (Many of us are still reeling from a storm last week that led to a declaration of emergency. Our borough looked like a war zone. Streets ripped up, houses smashed. We were 140 hours without power.)

@john ezra

Actually, the Kansas town is a no H town, like the one in California.

@john ezra

I moved to Pittsburgh to work for Westinghouse Electric in 1960 right after graduation and married a girl born and raised in the city.  That was just after Renaissance One had removed most of the black smoke from the sky.  Spent my entire career there.

Watching the 1960 World Series with a roomful of natives was a traumatic experience.

That is not my only connection.  My father left a job in the NYC offices of US Steel to work in the mills at Homestead and Gary in the 1920s.  That was the time when the Smoky City had to turn the streetlights on at noon.  The story is that my grandmother and aunt finally got on a train and persuaded him to return to NY.

I'm still a Yankees fan but I quickly adopted the Steelers and later the Penguins as "my" teams.

@John Ezra The story I know from somewhere (maybe having taught an SAT class in Pittsburg, TX, many years ago) is that the because there was so much variation in the use of 'h' in the various Pittsburg/Pittsburghs  around the country, the USPS instigated a requirement of a standardized no 'h' spelling to avoid confusion.  However, the OG largest former Pittsburgh in Pennsylvania had enough political clout to have its 'h' restored, while other, smaller Pittsburgs in the U.S. remained H-less.  I am aware that a quick Google would likely solve reveal the facts of history (and that the existence of a Pittsburgh, Kansas, would put the lie to the story), but I think that here it's best to not  let the truth get in the way of a good story.

@JayTee

Thanks for the correction...passed through Pittsburg KS once in the 1990s and haven't really thought about it since, so my memory put the h back on its name. So it goes...

@Jane Wheelaghan

Yes, I think it must be a Scottish nod, that h, not German.  Like Edinburgh.  And Teresa from Berlin in this thread points out that the "h" is not common in  her county. Scotland it is!

@john ezra
I have always assumed it was the Scottish influence, maybe because I once tried to count the Presbyterian churches here. I gave up.
@Jane Wheelaghan - reminds me of the -boro/-borough situation in North Carolina, with Hillsborough being the sole town to officially regain its -ugh in 1965 after having dropped it.
@john ezra I moved to Pittsburgh from the New York area and love living here.  I never bothered to change my location but really enjoy reading your comments

@john ezra thank you for the shout out and your post, which jogged my memory of an exhibit at the Heinz History Center where I think I learned some of that for the first time.

@Lily
'Yinz' and 'yin' is used a lot in Scots dialect. 
My younger bothers and sisters were the 'wee yinz',
'High heid yinz' - high-head ones eg managers, government
'Auld yin' - old one - mother, father, grandparent (fondly)
Big yin - used for friends and family, "How are ye, big yin?"
and nickname for Billy Connoly.

"I definitely had to 'warsh' the car.  I guess I stole the 'r' from 'library', which I pronounced as 'libary'. It still is an effort to remember to pronounce them correctly."

@Francis

Warsaw is Warszawa in Polish. It was probably named for the medieval owner of the settlement, the knight Warsz. According to legend though the name comes from the names Wars and Sawa, who, according to one version of the legend, were happy lovers - the poor fisherman Wars and the beautiful siren Sawa. This explains the origins of Warsaw's coat of arms - a siren. In another version, Wars and Sawa were poor man and wife who gave refuge to the local prince who got lost during a hunt, not knowing who he was.

@EmptyJ Colorado has a bunch of lame town names! My favorites include Rifle (named after litter, a rifle, found by the river) and Silt (named after a grain size). When I pointed this out to my Colo-born coworker, he got very defensive. He asked me what were names where I came from (Ohio). At the time, I came up with three rivers: Cuyahoga, Monongahela, and Youghiogheny. (Two of these happen to be near Pittsburgh.) He said "well, what do those mean??" My answer was "I don't know, something like silt." Not a chuckle.

@Francis

So good they named it zero times.

@Francis

Is it possible that that name refers to the Pueblo Indians?

Renegator,

The Pueblo peoples of the southwest were so called by the Spanish because of their distinctive villages. "Pueblo" was not their term for themselves.

@Renegator Apparently a trading post named El Pueblo was the first settlement on the site. It's described as trading with Ute and Apache people. My reference says it could accommodate up to 100 people, so maybe that's the origin of the name. https://www.legendsofamerica.com/fort-pueblo/

@Barry Ancona

I don't think that would impact how a place was named by European settlers.

And sometimes misunderstandings would take place.

I believe Schenectady NY got its name when a European asked a native (Mohawk, I believe) what they called a place he pointed to. The native answered something like "beyond the pines." 

I was taught that that was similar to someone asking me what's that place called and me answering I call it "that place over there," meaning it had no name and I just used general terms to refer to it.

Scottish car-wash laws:
1. It always rains when you've just washed your car.
2. But trying to make it rain by washing your car will never work. Don't trifle with the Laws of Nature.

@Jay  Amps—short for amplifiers for sound projection. Parkour is a physical activity that’s acrobatic and rather frenetic and amazing. Basically you try to get from one place to another in the fastest, shortest, and wildest, most acrobatic way possible—turning obstacles into ways to get to your destination, but with no tools or other help doing it. Think of the wildest movie scenes of chases along rooftops and down into alleys in action movies. Kind of hard to describe but wildly fun to watch.

@Jay AMPS as in amplifiers that musicians use on stage during performances. PARKOUR as in the activity practitioners use as to get around cities and such, jumping across buildings and skirting through alleyways up fire escapes, etc--essentially using the urban landscape as their "playground".

@David Connell

Kościuszko is considered a hero in Poland not only for his achievments in the American struggle for independence but also as the leader of the Polish 1794 uprising against the dominance of foreign powers in Poland.

In the 16th century Poland became one of the most powerful countries in the region, a regional superpower. However, disastrous wars of the 17th century (with Russia, Sweden, Turkey, etc.) caused a great decline from which Poland never recovered.

By the end of the 18th century, Poland's neighbors - Russia, Prussia and Austria - had engaged in the partition of Poland, taking away bits of the country. Kościuszko led an insurrection against occupying Russians in 1794, but it ended in distaster. Heroic the struggle may have been, but in reality it contributed to the ultimate downfall of the whole country. In the aftermath of the uprising, the final partition of Poland came in 1795 and the country disappeared from the world map for 123 years, to reemerge only in 1918 - us Polish people remain grateful to the US president Woodrow Wilson for his support of Polish independence at the time.

@David Connell. Growing up in the NYC area, we heard constant traffic updates on AM radio (usually 1010 WINS and WCBS 880).  They often mentioned traffic issues on the Kościuszko Bridge on the BQE and the Pulaski Skyway in New Jersey.  So I read up on the two as a kid, history nut that I am. 

Now, whenever I go over them, I give a little nod of thanks to these amazing people.

@pat in oregon

The crossed out clue yields a whimsical or absurd answer, that you then add an H at the end to make the answer to the non-crossed clue. Just as you add an H to the end of Pittsburg to make the now correct spelling Pittsburgh for 62A.

So, 16A, you might bid farewell to artist Marc Chagall by saying "Peace, Marc."
Add an H, and you have PEACE MARCH, a nonviolent protest.

Dear Jennie

@jennie

I'm very glad you're not a moderator on this board.

@jennie

I have a good friend for 45 years now.  When I first met her, she had such an agreeable personality, and it seemed she liked so many of the same things I did.

As time passed, I realized that she was brought up with the "if you can't say anything nice..." mentality, and simply was being "nice".  Nothing wrong with that, but over time, I realized I had no idea what she really liked.  And whether, when she said she liked something, she really meant it.

In the end, I just got to accept her the way she was, but in reality, there's nothing wrong with politely expressing that you don't like something.

As far as "if you want to see the replies, get a subscription" goes, you apparently having been paying attention.  The current problem is affecting people who have subscriptions.

As far as Eddie goes, I don't think "I done did this puzz" adds much to the conversation, and I was amazed that his daily comment was amassing reccos in a cult-like way.

@Eric Hougland

Why some comments get a lot of reccos and others don’t continues to baffle me. Even among my own comments, sometimes I’m startled to find my perfectly unusual comment on the top of Reader’s Picks; sometimes I think I’ve written an amazing post, and it gets 2 reccos.
